instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to carbon fiber-reinforced plastics (CFRP) structured by nanosecond pulsed laser?
Output: To carbon fiber-reinforced plastics (CFRP) structured by nanosecond pulsed laser,the researchers used visible spectrum and nir spectrum.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to carbon fiber-reinforced plastics (CFRP) structured by nanosecond pulsed laser?
Output: Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) was used to scan the pre-treated area and detect the surface quality of the CFRP structured by nanosecond pulsed laser.

instruction: What metric was chosen to carbon fiber-reinforced plastics (CFRP) structured by nanosecond pulsed laser and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to structure carbon fiber-reinforced plastics (CFRP) was the ablation pattern, which can simulate the influence of different thicknesses of matrix layers above the carbon fibers. The ablation pattern can go as far as determining the quality conditions of the laser-structured CFRP surfaces.

instruction: What machine learning techniques were used to develop prediction models based on the hyperspectral imaging (HSI) data in the study that aimed to predict the success of metallic coatings on carbon fiber-reinforced plastics (CFRP) structured by nanosecond pulsed laser?
Output: U-Net CNNs were used to develop prediction models based on the hyperspectral imaging (HSI) data in the study.

instruction: Can the use of hyperspectral imaging (HSI) technologies in conjunction with deep learning provide a more reliable and objective evaluation method for predicting the success of metallic coatings on carbon fiber-reinforced plastics (CFRP) structured by nanosecond pulsed laser, compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, the use of hyperspectral imaging (HSI) technologies in conjunction with deep learning can provide a more reliable and objective evaluation method for predicting the success of metallic coatings on carbon fiber-reinforced plastics (CFRP) structured by nanosecond pulsed laser, compared to traditional methods. The study utilized HSI-based prediction models, which were able to accurately predict, with an accuracy of around 80%, which laser-treated areas will successfully be coated and which will not. This objective and automatic evaluation method allows for the avoidance of large amounts of rejects before further processing the parts and also helps optimize the adhesion of coatings. Additionally, the spatially resolved data obtained through HSI enables local reworking during the laser process, making it possible to achieve zero waste in the manufacturing process.
